But if,” added he, “ I were utterly to destroy all the savages in Chaco, at the expense of two soldiers only, verily‚ on my return to the city, I should expect to be saluted with mud and stones. The people are extremely desirous of the deaths of the savages, but expect their own soldiers to be immortal in every battle.'' As it had been clearly proved that Barreda was by no means rash in undertaking expeditioris, the people of St. Iago with willing minds followed whither- soever he led, and under no leader did these excellent soldiers make more daring achieve- ments.

I have already mentioned that the people of St.1ago possessed a singular skill at exploring, but that Landriel excelled in this respect is doubted by no one. Barreda made use of him sor many years as the chief instrument of his victories; and by this penetrating discoverer of the savages he was accompanied wherever he went. Other Spaniards, too, out of the territories of St. Iago, took him for their guide whenever the savages were to be attacked or repelled.
